The irregularity in the electron affinity trend between Cl and F is due to the small size of the F atom. Although F definitely has a higher attraction for an electron than Cl (as evidenced by its high electronegativity value), the small size of the F atom means that adding an electron creates significant repulsion. As a result, fluorine has an electron affinity less than that of chlorine.

You need 8 in the OUTER shell to be complete.

So in chlorine's first shell, it as 2 electrons. In the next shell, it has 8 electrons. And in its outer shell, it has 7, for a total of 17 (which is also the number of protons it has, and its atomic number). In order to be complete, it needs 1 more electron, which will give it 8 electrons in the outer shell, and 18 electrons total.
